description: Stocks in Asia Pacific were mostly positive in Friday afternoon trade as investors await the U.S. nonfarm payrolls report expected later in the day stateside.
text:
Stocks in Asia Pacific were mostly positive in Friday afternoon trade as
investors await the U.S. nonfarm payrolls report expected later in the day
stateside. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 rose 0.45% in afternoon trade while the
Topix index added 0.25%. South Korea's Kospi jumped 1.24% as shares of LG Chem
surged more than 3%. Mainland Chinese stocks, however, were lower by the
afternoon. The Shanghai composite dipped 0.26% while the Shenzhen component
slipped 0.329%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index was largely flat. Meanwhile, the
S&P/ASX 200 in Australia stood little changed. Overall, the MSCI Asia ex-Japan
index rose 0.27%. Developments on economic stimulus as countries attempt to
recover from the coronavirus pandemic likely continued to be watched. The
European Central Bank on Thursday announced an increase in its Pandemic
Emergency Purchase Programme by 600 billion euros . Overnight stateside, the
S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite saw their first decline in five sessions. The
moves on Wall Street came as the Labor Department said 1.877 million Americans
filed for unemployment benefits last week, higher than a Dow Jones estimate of
1.775 million. Investors will now look ahead to the Labor Department's monthly
jobs report release, expected at 8:30 a.m. ET Friday. "Every single leading
indicator for non-farm payrolls that we follow signal fewer job losses but a
number of these reports saw only small improvements which means that non-farm
payrolls, while better could miss expectations," Kathy Lien, managing director
of foreign exchange strategy at BK Asset Management, wrote in a note. The U.S.
dollar index , which tracks the greenback against a basket of its peers, was
last at 96.75 following an earlier low of 96.715. The Japanese yen traded at
109.18 per dollar after weakening from levels below 108 earlier in the trading
week. The Australian dollar changed hands at $0.6957 following its rise from
levels below $0.68 seen earlier this week. Oil prices rose in the afternoon of
Asian trading hours, with international benchmark Brent crude futures up 0.48%
to $40.18 per barrel. U.S. crude futures also added 0.19% to $37.48 per
barrel.

title: Asia Pacific stocks mostly higher ahead of U.S. jobs report [CNBC]
html: Stocks in Asia Pacific were mostly positive in Friday afternoon trade as investors await the U.S. nonfarm payrolls report expected later in the day stateside. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 rose 0.45% in afternoon trade while the Topix index added 0.25%. South Korea's Kospi jumped 1.24% as shares of LG Chem surged more than 3%. Mainland Chinese stocks, however, were lower by the afternoon. The Shanghai composite dipped 0.26% while the Shenzhen component slipped 0.329%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index was largely flat. Meanwhile, the S&P/ASX 200 in Australia stood little changed. Overall, the MSCI Asia ex-Japan index rose 0.27%. Developments on economic stimulus as countries attempt to recover from the coronavirus pandemic likely continued to be watched. The European Central Bank on Thursday announced an increase in its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme by 600 billion euros . Overnight stateside, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite saw their first decline in five sessions. The moves on Wall Street came as the Labor Department said 1.877 million Americans filed for unemployment benefits last week, higher than a Dow Jones estimate of 1.775 million. Investors will now look ahead to the Labor Department's monthly jobs report release, expected at 8:30 a.m. ET Friday. "Every single leading indicator for non-farm payrolls that we follow signal fewer job losses but a number of these reports saw only small improvements which means that non-farm payrolls, while better could miss expectations," Kathy Lien, managing director of foreign exchange strategy at BK Asset Management, wrote in a note. The U.S. dollar index , which tracks the greenback against a basket of its peers, was last at 96.75 following an earlier low of 96.715. The Japanese yen traded at 109.18 per dollar after weakening from levels below 108 earlier in the trading week. The Australian dollar changed hands at $0.6957 following its rise from levels below $0.68 seen earlier this week. Oil prices rose in the afternoon of Asian trading hours, with international benchmark Brent crude futures up 0.48% to $40.18 per barrel. U.S. crude futures also added 0.19% to $37.48 per barrel.
